title: It's great when it works, but the last two of these we've had have gone bad in under a month.
text:
We've purchased four of these from Amazon. The first had great flavor and flow the full 200 gallons/6 months.

The second started tasting horrid in under a month.

The third tasted fine but slowed to a trickle within a couple of weeks. It would say it took 70+oz to fill a 16oz glass.

I'm returning the third one and have a fourth filter in — the third in less than two months. If it doesn't last, I'm switching to Kenwood coz this is ridiculous.

title: Exactly what I needed
text:
We recently moved into a new home, and the home came with the refrigerator. I had never had a refrigerator with a functional ice/water dispenser on the door before, and was really excited to begin using it. Upon opening my fridge, I noticed the water filter replacement light was bright red. I googled which filter I needed for my particular brand of fridge, and purchased it on Amazon.

Upon delivery, I was a little stressed out because I had never replaced a water filter before, but it actually took longer to open the plastic packaging, than it did to replace the water filter. I ran a few gallons of water through it, as recommended by other reviews, and removed all of the pre-existing ice from the freezer compartment.

I now have delicious tasting ice and water, and the water filter light is green. :)

title: Does not reduce Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)
text:
You may find reviews discounting the importance of a TDS measurement talking about what it doesn't measure. Those miss the point. Ok, there might be some other bad stuff that might get removed that is not part of a TDS measurement. That's great. However, that doesn't change the fact that TDS is measuring OTHER CONTAMINANTS THAT STILL REMAIN.

The Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) National Secondary Drinking Water Regulations (NSDWRs) limit TDS to 500mg/L. This filter does not reduce TDS below this level.

From the Environmental Protection Agency's Website:

National Secondary Drinking Water Regulations (NSDWRs)
NSDWRs (or secondary standards) are non-enforceable guidelines regulating contaminants that may cause cosmetic effects (such as skin or tooth discoloration) or aesthetic effects (such as taste, odor, or color) in drinking water. EPA recommends secondary standards to water systems but does not require systems to comply with the standard. However, states may choose to adopt them as enforceable standards

List of National Secondary Drinking Water Regulations
Contaminant Secondary Standard
Aluminum 0.05 to 0.2 mg/L
Chloride 250 mg/L
Color 15 (color units)
Copper 1.0 mg/L
Corrosivity noncorrosive
Fluoride 2.0 mg/L
Foaming Agents 0.5 mg/L
Iron 0.3 mg/L
Manganese 0.05 mg/L
Odor 3 threshold odor number
pH 6.5-8.5
Silver 0.10 mg/L
Sulfate 250 mg/L
Total Dissolved Solids 500 mg/L
Zinc 5 mg/L

title: The only filter that significantly improves taste and reduces TDS
text:
On a quest for the best tasting water possible from a refrigerator, I decided to try out a few different filters with a TDS meter. I started with a 1/3 price filter and even after flushing gallons through, the water had visible specks and the TDS actually increased when going through the filter instead of decreasing.

This EveryDrop filter decreased my TDS by 50-100 ppm (depending on when I measure, not sure if it’s a meter inaccuracy or if my tap is just changing through the days) and the taste difference is astonishing compared to the other knockoff filters. I didn’t want to pay $50+ for the filter but I will say it’s worth it.

However, I don’t think it actually lasts a full 6 months of great taste. My previous EveryDrop filter was 6.5-7 months old prior to replacement and the taste had been just okay for several months.

title: Fails Impurity Testing - Not Much Better Than Tap Water - Complete Ripoff
text:
I had purchased some generic filters in the past and was curious to know if they actually worked or if they were a ripoff so I bought a total dissolved solids meter on Amazon for about $15 and tested the water. Absolutely pure water does not conduct electricity. As amount of impurities in that water increases (which also include good things such as minerals) its ability to conduct electricity also increases and a TDS meter measures this and translates it to parts per million of TDS. Well those generic filters did not filter anything from the water as the TDS meter indicated the same ppm TDS for both samples.

So I decided to go ahead and spend the extra money on a "quality" filter. Well after installing and running 1 gallon through there was no change between tap water and the water coming our of my fridge. Same results after 5 gallons. Now 2 weeks later and the family using the water dispenser the water tests about 20 ppm less than tap water. May tap tests at 340 ppm give or take 15 depending on the day. I also tested demineralized water which came in at 3 ppm and bottled Dasani water which was 15 ppm.

AN ABSOLUTE AND COMPLETE RIPOFF TAKING ADVANTAGE OF TRUSTING CUSTOMERS!!! Essentially stealing your money and is criminal.

Other reviews echo this same result. I encourage everyone to also conduct this testing. There should be a class action lawsuit...

title: Doesn't Last That Long; Water Flavor is Fine
text:
Installing this filter is a breeze on my fridge. Open the filter hatch to pop out the previous one, insert the new one, and close the hatch. The biggest annoyance when installing a new filter is how much water you have to flush (4 gallons) before it's considered ready for use.

My everydrop filters tend to last only 3 months before the flow of water starts to slow down. My wife and I do drink a lot of water, but I'd expect it to last longer than that. My most recent filter made it about 2.5 months before the water flow slowed to a weak stream, and my city's water has a really low PPM count (~25-50ppm). I don't want to spend $45 every 3 months of the year on filters, but ultimately I'm stuck using these because it's what fits in my fridge.

title: How I fixed the problem with these filters causing water stoppage- for a while!
text:
Overall, I have always bought these authentic Whirlpool filters, despite their price, because I had read horror stories about leaks with generic versions. I have never had a leak with a real Whirlpool filter.

One problem I had this last time, which others have had, is that after the initial purge of 3 gallons, after a short while the water would start to trickle and then stop. Nothing. I read about air in the line, so I followed the instructions of dispensing water for 5 seconds, then waiting again for another 5 seconds before resuming, and repeating countless times. What a pain! But it continued to have the problem. After a few dispenses, the water would stop flowing. I found that if I removed the filter and snapped it back in, it would work for a few times, but the water not coming from the dispenser would just keep on coming back, until it hardly worked at all.

I figured there was air in the FILTER. So, I washed the exterior well, and then submerged it in a deep container full of water (I washed it so that any dirt or contamination would enter the filter). Sure enough, I could see air very slowly popping out of one of the two opening. A small bubble, then pop, then another, then another. I left it submerged for several hours until I was sure that I saw no more bubbles (I would also occasionally agitate it to help the air escape). I then reinstalled it, and it has worked flawlessly ever since.

So, if you have the same problem, that would be my suggestion.

UPDATE: This worked for a good while, and then the same issue. Somehow air keeps on infiltrating the filter and causing stoppage of the water flow. Take it out and water flower perfectly. Very frustrating to do this every week or two.

title: Ridiculously expensive but way better than the knock-off brands
text: I used to purchase the Whirlpool brand years ago (back when the filters were $60+) and then I found the knock-offs for significantly less.  After a few years of using the non-Whirlpool brands it was very clear that those filters were not exact spec filters as they would technically fit the connectors but there was always some odd thing.  The filters would be a 1/4" too long, wouldn't have the same water flow spec, cheap filter elements, etc.  But, for the cost I didn't care.  Fast forward to now and it seems as if Whirlpool has been successful at shutting down some (not all) of these knockoff filters.  So, I was forced to buy the Whirlpool filter, and, I have to admit the more expensive filter is head and shoulders better.  The water flow is *much* better, the filter material is better and the filter itself is an exact and precise fit.  Having to replace these every 6 months (sometimes more if you have harder water) doesn't give me joy but the alternative gives me less joy (crappy imitation filters.)

title: Not very effective
text: Not sure if this filter is doing anything. The tap water in Woodinville Washington has about 28 parts per million (ppm) when measuring total dissolved solids (tds).  Measuring the water filtered with this filter I get 27ppm tds.  Not sure if paying $50 makes sense when safe level is 800+ppm, tap water is 28ppm for Seattle suburb, and this filter only reduces 1ppm.  I'd expect the TDS to be 0 for what this filter is commanding in terms of price.

title: So Frustrated...!!!
text: For some reason this water filter is a lemon.  I installed it in my refrigerator and started to run water through it.  Water ran for approx. 15 to 20 seconds and then stopped.  I replaced the old filter and water runs through it fine.  I repeated the new install 4 times and each time it would no longer run ANY water through.  So....the frustration is that Amazon says any returns have to go through the manufacturer which would be Whirlpool.  I called Whirlpool 4 or 5 times to only be put on hold indeffinately.  Finally I was able to get them to call me back at a specific time.  Twice they did, each time the lady said she had to get the "filter" department and then I was sent into another indeffinate hold.  I even tried the "live" chat...it is not live...it is a computer.  I was unable to chat with anyone at Whirlpool about my probloem.  Filters are not cheap...but I'm forced to buy another one (this time from a local dealer).  If anyone can help me I would very much appreciate it.

title: Lasts one month
text: We have had to replace these every month since getting a new refrigerator three months ago, despite the 6 month/200 gallon promise. We are a big family, but we are not drinking 200 gallons of water a month. These filters are about half the size of those required by our previous refrigerator, also a whirlpool. Those also had the 6 month/200 gallon promise and usually lasted us 3 months, sometimes 2, which was acceptable because we are a big family. To add insult to injury, the new fridge dispenser shuts down and refuses to dispense water once it deems a replacement is necessary. This happened exactly at the wrong time when we had many guests over for holidays. Whole experience makes us feel like yet another victim of corporate greed. Not happy whirlpool.

title: Great Taste for 4 Weeks
text: We used to buy these filters and they lasted 6 months as per the manufacturer's indication. Recently, they've been lasting only 4-6 weeks. I don't know if they changed the filter media in the manufacturing of these, but they're not the same filters they used to be. I even went to the effort to verify and replace all the other components of my fridge water system thinking the problem was other than the filters. Alas, the filters were still clogging after a few weeks. I had my water supply tested and found no increase in sediments or other minerals. I've now switched to a 3-stage filter connected to the fridge supply line. I just couldn't justify $50/month for the fridge filter.

title: UPDATED REVIEW BELOW: Popped out and had water leaking inside fridge
text: PREVIOUS REVIEW: Popped out and won't go back in. Have used these before with no problem. This one does not work. UPDATED REVIEW OF SAME FILTER: Called Everydrop and came to the conclusion that there probably was air in the line. Make sure filter is in good with door closed then run dispenser for about 5 seconds then off then run another 5 seconds to clear air on the line. What worked for me was that I made sure the water filter was NOT installed and closed the filter door. Ran water through the dispenser some which may have cleared some air. Then open filter door and put filter back in and made sure it was in securely with filter door closed. Did the run off of 4 gallons or so and no problem.

title: Like many others are saying, the filters act clogged and after only one day.
text:
[[VIDEOID:85408b7b4c39d495d4713adfe2e36597]] Bought two and installed one. Purged the air and everything worked fine for a day or two, then the water output started sputtering and was cloudy when dispensing. Removed/reseated the filter several times, and each time it would run fine for approx 8 oz, then it would sputter and become cloudy each time. Finally, all water flow ended and my water pump could be heard cavitating (knocking) as if the filter was clogged.

Installed my 2nd unused filter, purged all air by running it through, then flow immediately stopped and pump started cavitating again. No sputtering this time; only pump cavitation. Tested a couple of more times before deciding to stop so as to not damage the pump.

Operation is normal with filters removed.

It seems that several other people have experienced this problem.

title: Doesn't last very long AT ALL!
text: I'm not sure what the deal is.  I have, already several filters plus an R/O and water softener coming into my house (overkill I know but I can't seem to find a bypass plug for the fridge) and this stopped up after about a week of use.  Granted I do drink a ton of water probably bring 3-4 gallons through the fridge daily between what I drink and the family, still I would have thought with my water already being filtered and this just being basically for taste it would last a bit longer.  I put it in middle of January and have been dealing with trickling water until now my fridge is telling me to change it.  Not happy at all, especially since it didn't seem to taste any different then the cheap filter I had to wait 12 days for.  Guess I'll be waiting or trying to find another solution, I would be ok if it lasted 5 or 6 months of good flow but this is way to expensive to filter already good quality water if I need to change this frequently.

title: Possibly Used Filters?
text: I have bought 2 replacement filters from Amazon and most recently picked one up from Lowes.  The one I bought from Lowes was a couple of dollars more expensive, but it came with more peace of mind. I'm not certain that the ones bought off Amazon weren't previously used.  When you insert the new filter in your refrigerator, the first gallon or so comes out very cloudy.  This is normal as the instructions say that you should flush 3 or 4 gallons before drinking water that has flowed through the new filter.  When I installed the filters I bought from Amazon, there was never any cloudy water.  This is why I believe the filters I received from Amazon were previously used.  I love Amazon and do not particularly like going to B&M stores, but this is one item that I will continue to buy from hardware stores instead of Amazon.

title: Clearer ice cubes. Cost vs value
text: The Whirlpool refrigerator/freezer filter is expensive for what it is. I suppose an “off brand” filter would have cost less. There are so many different filters that promise to do different things. It’s a little confusing, and there are a lot of scam filters on the market, so I figured I’d go with the Whirlpool endorsed filter. Since installing and after a couple days of discarding the new ice cubes, the ice cubes do appear to be clearer. There is no apparent taste in drinks. I don’t have the water function in my refrigerator, so I can’t evaluate drinking water. I would say filtered ice cubes is a good thing if you’re either OCD (which I am) or if you believe you have a water issue. I would also say you could save a few dollars by shopping around for the filter that does what you’re looking for it to do. It seems buying multiple filters at once does save a few dollars on each filter, if you have a place to store them. I’m not sure the filter is worth the cost I paid for it. With summer coming, time will tell. Do your research. $100 per year for clearer ice cubes is not a small expense. You have to weigh cost versus value, just like anything else.

text: About six months ago I purchased a three pack of inexpensive refrigerator filters. My wife really complained about chlorine taste in the water. Additionally I must have flushed five gallons or more before that cloudy water went away. Finally I decided to buy this product and throw the cheap brand away. What a difference. No chlorine taste at all. It’s a pleasure to drink water again from the refrigerator. Took me 30 seconds to install and only flushed about two gallons of water before the water was clear. Wife is very happy. The product isn’t cheap. But I guess you get what you pay for.

title: FILTER WORKS GREAT, BUT INTERACTION WITH FRIDGE LEAVES ME WITH QUESTIONS....
text:
I live in an area where carefully filtered water is an absolute must. This fridge was crazy expensive, so I baby it. I got it at a huge discount ($750 off normal price) and I'll never be able to afford to replace it. That said, I am REALLY careful about everything with it.

Because of the nature of the water where I live, I know that the filter will have to be replaced A LOT more often than in areas without the problems of this area. So I am careful to always check the indicator light inside the fridge. But in approximately 6 months, it never came on!! That really bothered me. So I started researching online. I found sites and forums where people had had similar questions (apparently, this is a thing?) and did not know when they should change the filter. The most useful advice I found was that you know the filter needs changing when the flow from the water-in-the-door isn't as fast as it was in the beginning. I had not even noticed this because the reduction in flow had been so gradual. So I changed the filter and the difference was immediately noticeable. So, now I have put this filter on subscription and now I will replace it every time a new one is delivered. Problem solved.

The reason I gave it only 4 stars instead of 5 is that the relationship between the filter and the functionality of the fridge is not clearly explained by either provider -- not Whirlpool (the manufacturer of the fridge) nor by the manufacturer of the filter. Nothing is explained about what causes the light to come on or when it is suitable to change the filter. And I don't know whose responsibility this ought to be. But, to my mind, the filter company bears a certain amount of responsibility in managing the expectations of the buyers so that they know how to best use the product.

title: Great filter and easy to use!
text:
My three main reasons for using fresh filters are A) to try to reduce corrosion in the pipes/tubing in the fridge, B) to make sure the fridge can produce ice and C) to consistently minimize chlorine/chloramine in the water.

Since I do a lot of outdoor and indoor gardening, including hydroponics, I have a few different tools for measuring water quality PPM, parts per million of total dissolved solids. I have a large undersink filter in my kitchen and this filter installed in the refrigerator.

When I test my prefiltered water PPM it swings from 100 to upwards of 150 PPM, and I've seen it go higher on occasion as well. When testing the large undersink and this refrigerator filtered water they are both consistently 100 PPM. The reason I keep buying them is because at times when our water is worse, these filters keep the PPM stable at a decent number.

I can also attest that my refrigerator ice maker will not function when the filter is close to end of life. I was curious is that was happening because it was aware when the filter was expiring, so I chose to not "reset" the filter when I replaced it last and the ice maker started working again.

That all being said, this filter checks all my boxes, keeps everyone happy with ice making and keeps my organic soil chlorine free and happy as well :)

title: Got a counterfeit or damaged product.
text: I bought an EveryDrop by Whirlpool Refrigerator Water Filter 1, EDR1RXD1 from Amazon per the link on Everydrop's website on August 21, installed it that week, and the water dispenser seemed louder but water flowed fine.  Last night the fridge ejected the water filter -- just opened the door and pushed it out.  It won't go back in.  Water dispenses without the excess noise now. I think the Amazon product was a counterfeit or damaged. The ones I've gotten from Everydrop directly worked fine.  Do not buy from this site.  Can't get a refund and I'm not hassling with returning a canister of chemicals.

title: Amazon has the best of all the ridiculous prices
text:
You remember that sweet deal you got on your fridge? Of course you do! Now, we just need you to subscribe to our plan to get a new water filter every six month and the low low price of just $100 a year. You can cancel anytime, but you wont, because you need water filters for your fridge.

Sound familiar? You probably got something like that in the mail after you purchased your appliance. Competition pushed the profit margins on appliances way down, and this is how they are making it up on the consumer, many times over.

If my refrigerator lasts 10 years with no other maintenance, I will have spent quite a bit more in filters alone that I paid for the appliance itself. I will give props to amazon, they do have the best price around on this filter, and I checked everywhere.

All in all, it's such a great scam, I wish I had thought of it. I'm so addicted to the great taste of the water that comes from this filter, I'll just keep buying them. I can't help it. Maybe they put drugs in it.

2 stars off for the ridiculous pricing of these filters...but my advice is to just grab a straw, suck it up, and buy it here anyway.

title: Used for our Whirlpool Refrigerator WRS325SDHZ
text:
Whatever refrigerator you own, it's important that you go to your respective manufacturer's site to ensure you're getting the correct filter. The way these refrigerators are built, you're either going to have to ride it out with the old one (not recommended) or get a new one. There's no way to get around not having a water filter in one of these things.
Our water often gets a little swampy tasting in the summer months, so the Every Drop #1 Ice & Water filter really does make a marked difference in taste for me. We also have hard water, so at around the 7th or 8th month of use, I begin to notice the filter has run its course.

We have the Whirlpool 36-inch side-by-side model (WRS325SDHZ). To get to the filter, you have to open the freezer side and look for the latch on the bottom of the base. Pop it open and take note of the arrow (pointing to the left). Pull it out, take of the tip protector of the new one, and slide it in,making sure the arrow points to the left, and you're done.

If you have the Whirlpool WRS325SDHZ refrigerator and you're looking for a replacement water filter, you've found it.

text:
This filter is good. But it’s very pricey. I try to stretch it out as much as possible. Eventually the ice quality becomes pretty poor because the filter gets clogged.

Lasts about as advertised. Easy to install.

My Fridge has a water dispenser. I usually flush it out on first use, until there is no particles in the water. If you have ice only, definitely dump quite a few cycles before consuming.

Don’t buy generic. They clog up very quick and don’t filter the water all that great. You get what you pay for in this case.

If you buy 2 filters a year, Costs about $100 plus tax. Pricey but worth it. I try to wait for sales and buy one ahead of time. When I put a new one in I usually prefer to keep a spare in my kitchen draw.

Overall reliable filter. Just wish it was cheaper.

title: Starting to clog and become unusable after a short while
text:
I've been ordering these for many years now. In the past once the filter gets dirty, you simply notice the water start to taste different. No changes in the water flow.

However during the past 3 filters I've had, these do not change the filter's taste anymore. Rather it stops the water flow. You have to then shake or tap it quit hard on a solid surface to knock around the materials inside. I'm guessing the pebbles inside clog the water inlet or outlets. When this happens, your refrigerator will not let water flow.

What upset me is that they are only a few months old and hardly been used and it starts clogging. The water taste haven't changed. But it's already clogging and will force me to buy a new one before its time. I think that might be the manufacturer's point. They're not cheap.

I'm looking into putting an external water line filter. They're far far cheaper and does just as good a job.

title: This is a total fraud, and I am not the only person who ran the same water purity tests.
text:
BUYER BEWARE (of Everydrop by Whirlpool Ice and Water Refrigerator Filter 1, EDR1RXD1):
I tested the "Everydrop by Whirlpool Ice and Water Refrigerator Filter 1, EDR1RXD1" that came with our new Whirlpool refrigerator and compared it to plain tap-water, and with tap-water passed through a ZERO Water filter, using three different water testers.
The Whirlpool filter was only 1%-to-2% better than tap water (at about 150ppm).
The water passed through the ZERO water filter was 2, 1, or ZERO.
I am not the only person that discovered this.

I refuse to buy any more of these Whirlpool filters until a adequate solution is provided.
In my opinion, this borders on fraud (i.e. $45 for a filter that is no better than tap-water).

title: Update: Refund requested! Latest ordered one slightly different size than last so doesn’t work anymore.
text:
Original September purchase: product came in original manuf packaging, fits well and works fine.

12 March Update #2: went for more water and got the hammering sound. Upon opening the filter cartridge area, the paper towel I used to pad the cartridge is now soaked. Redid papertowel (little thicker) and when I went back to check on it a couple hours later, paper towel getting wet again. Just submitted a refund request. Will try to buy from a brick/mortar store to see if I have better luck or even try to find an alternate option. Will see what works!

12 March Update: bought again but had issues when I installed it. I’d get a hammering noise and then no water would flow. Searched high and low for the ‘how to fix’ and found it on a YouTube video. The latest cartridge I received was ever so slightly smaller than the last one, so it was making a complete seal when the filter compartment lid was closed. So upon advice from the YouTube video I put in a folded piece of paper towel (about 1/4 sheet folded up) btwn cartridge and door and Voila - it worked w/out issued! No hammering noise and water flows freely. Will update again if this changes anytime soon!

title: Good replacement water filter for Whirlpool refrigerator

They recommend that you run some gallons of water out after you replace the filter. But you know how slow those water dispensers are on your refrigerator! It would take forever, so we haven't done it. I wish I knew why they tell you to do that.

title: How do you flush it?
text:

One star down.

title: Odd taste lately
text: I’ve been using these filters for several years, and signed up for “subscribe & save” for convenience.  A few months ago, I noticed an odd taste in the water after installing a new filter.  When I contacted Whirlpool (they sell the identical product, but it’s more expensive) they said they would only guarantee the filter if we bought directly from them.  So, I tossed the filter and put in a new one.  Now we are having the same problem again.  I hate to toss something so expensive only 2 weeks after installing it.  I always flush the new filter with the recommended 4 gallons of water, so that’s not the issue.  Are “factory seconds” ending up on Amazon?

title: How to unglogg
text: I have used this product over the period of 2 years replacing the filter four times. This morning I could not get the water to come out of the dispenser and when I looked at questions I saw that some people just thought it was a waste of a filter because they didn't know how to unclog it. I took the filter out put it upside down and shook it really really hard getting the excess water out and when it seemed like no more water would come out of the filter I reinserted it and hooray! The water is now working. So if any of you have a problem with the water dispenser stopping just take the filter out turn it upside down shake the heck out of it and then put it back in and it should get it unclogged and your dispenser working again. I thought it was important to write this review and this helpful tip in case this happened to someone else. I've had no other problems with the filter and I'm glad to have it and clean ice cubes and water dispensed from the refrigerator! It is a good buy

title: Totally ineffective and horrible customer service at EveryDrop!!
text: Worth a fifth of the price.  If you can find a cheaper knockoff buy it instead.  I faithfully stuck with this brand and model as it was the same as the one that came in my fridge.  I forked out $50 assuming this was the most effective option.  It did seem to slightly improved he flavor of the water, but the water still left nasty white residue on everything and sometimes smelled bad enough I struggled to drink it.  My suspicion that this filter was VERY ineffective when I recently bought a ZeroWater pitcher that included a TDS meter tool.  The first reading showed a TDS of 360 ppm for our tap water and 306 for this filter! Second test a day later showed 390 for the tap water and 372 for this filter.  The $15 filter included in the pitcher was able to bring it down to 0 ppm.  I know this one has to have a higher flow rate, but it is only stopping about 20% of the contaminants.  Should only cost $15-30 MAX!

title: Poor product support and too much non-recyclable waste
text:
Encased in a horrible non-recyclable plastic clamshell from the manufacturer. Why can't you just put it in cardboard? These things are already indestructible by themselves.

Also, the latest of these that I bought failed after two weeks (completely clogged, and we're on very clean city water). We called the manufacturer and they said "you have to call the seller, we can't help you."

So I contacted Amazon customer service. Since it had been on my shelf for more than 30 days since I ordered it, they didn't want to take it back. So beware of buying stuff before you need it, for example with Subscribe and Save. Amazon customer service told me to "test everything before 30 days" in case its defective, otherwise they won't help you. Obviously that is ridiculously impractical and inconvenient and makes the whole idea of subscribe and save very unattractive since you almost always get the stuff before you need it.

title: Forget these.
text:
I used to purchase these when they were [[ASIN:B0049IA8QK Whirlpool W10295370 FILTER1 Refrigerator Water Filter]] ... and they worked okay. They were nothing special, and the price is shocking for a what you get. I don't have the initiative or tools to take a bandsaw to one of these filters, but I bet there isn't any magic going on inside this cartridge, other than the neat trick of getting you to pay 20x what it costs to make the thing every 6 months.

After two years of paying for these things, I decided to research alternatives. I installed one of these at the top of the fridge:
[[ASIN:B000E77I0Y Watts 5YR Premier Filter 5-Year/20,000-Gallon Inline Ice Maker Water Filter]]
The economics are pretty self-evident. Even if you find yourself unable to install this filter, a handy friend or neighbor might be able to help you out for the price of a 12-pack of their favorite adult beverage. Go that route and save yourself enough money for fun things here on Amazon. Plus the water taste and quality seems comparable to me, perhaps even better.

I put a label in the fridge with the date of when I installed this 5-year filter so I know when to replace it -- and I just reset the stupid alert on the refrigerator door whenever it comes on.

text: The water filter market must be tough...nearly all of the Pur and other knockoff water filters for my particular fridge are all gone now. It doesn't make your water taste "better" per se, but it does make sure you're not getting any nasty aftertaste and the water does come out crystal clear.  My only beef is price.  For what it is, a fridge filter, this thing should be half the cost but whaddya do - Whirlpool has kinda a monopoly to charge what they want since they have so little competition.  Buy it...but I'd stretch it out the replacement cycle by a couple month or so...it can go much longer than the recommended replacement timeframe suggested.

title: It's good - read review
text: It's fine.. I read all these reviews about people measuring ppm and ph and waiting for black carbon to come out... This isn't a reverse osmosis system or even a high end filter.. most filters aren't if you really do your research on them. They're intended to help make it a little better than tap and make your ice a little cleaner. If you're a water freak, you need to invest in a much better sink top filter, a reverse osmosis system, or a whole house system. I use this to filter my ice just a little better than tap, and I use my aquasana sink top filter for water. If you expect better than that, to go spend big money on a reverse osmosis system.

title: This is the Whirlpool branded version
text:
There seems to be a real mis understanding of the water filter and what it is supposed to do. Several reviews are showing a TDS tester from the Zero water filter and stating it shows the same as the tap water.... CORRECT! Thats because you are measuring Hardness level not poisons!
The Whirlpool filter only removes harmful stuff such as Lead, 2, 4-D, Asbestos, Benzene, Carbofuran, Cysts, Endrin, Mercury, P-Dichlorobenzene, Particulates (class I), Toxaphene, Turbidity. It does not remove minerals... which for those of us that have espresso machines or pour over coffee pots need to retain the flavor of the beans. Water is a great cleaner and when you remove all of the minerals, it then wants to get them from somewhere. What i suggest for making espresso and coffee as well as iced tea and possibly even powerder drinks it use this filter to remove all of the sludge and poison, and then the zero water to reduce the hardness. For me its a 50/50 mix. i add in my refrigerator filtered water after the fact as well as the filtered tap water from the zero water pitcher. my TDS tester shows me at 48, which is almost in the center of what is recommended by the SCA for perfect espresso coffee water. So buy this with confidence. NO one should be drinking distilled water... its tastes like crap.

The three stars for "Easy to Install" is not to degrade this product at all, the issue is with the refrigerator's locking mechanism which broke and I have to use an adjustable spanner to pop out the old used filter to install the new one.

title: Caused a mini flood
text:
I had purchased this before but when I went to replace old filter, I could not get this to fit and water started spewing from the filter portal!! The water would not stop so I had a mini flood growing in the kitchen. I finally thought to put the old filter in and finally stopped the flow. I have reached out to Every Drop, Whirlpool ,and Pur to see if anyone can advise as to what filter I should buy as this is junk. I don't trust buying an Every Drop again. I read in these reviews that Pur used to supply the Every Drop filter but then started using a different brand and that's why the fittings don't load properly and that the length of the filter prevents the door from closing well. I'm hoping Pur actually has the filters that used their tech even tho Every Drop name is on the filters they sell on their site. My next call is to the store where I bought the fridge. Maybe they have had to deal with the repair problems caused by this filter and can rec a different one. Will update if anyone responds to my requests.

**Update** All 3 companies responded to my inquiry. Whirlpool is sending me a replacement filter so I will let you know if it works. I will also add pics of the first filter, current filter (w/probs), and new Whirlpool filter for folks to be able to compare. Every Drop and PUR told me to contact Whirlpool. I asked them to tell me specifically where I could buy a quality filter (as in the past) that would fit and both again referred me to Whirlpool. I am hopeful I can find a place to buy a good filter and will let you know details.

*Update 2* received Whirpool's replacement filter and the minute i felt it I could immediately tell it was so much lighter than the one I bought here. I then noticed the one I bought here had lots of stains on it as well. After weighing it, the Whirlpool one, and the one I had previously bought from here, I am convinced that the most recent one I bought from here was used. It weighed more than the other 2, was even dirty whereas the one I replaced was still clean looking. I personally think Amazon should shut down this seller for safety reasons. They lure you in w/a good filter and when you return to buy another, God knows what is in that filter, where it was used, potential diseases, etc. The filter that started all this mess must have messed up the filter line bc now I am having issues where there is air in the line, water won't stop flowing, etc. and this is a 1 yr old fridge so I am hoping Amazon will allow the truth to stay in my review.

title: Water quality worse than the old filter
text:
I purchased this to replace my old filter which was 10 months old. The old filter produced water with a TDS of 125 (even being 10 months old). The new filter, after flushing it exactly as instructed (and some extra) produced water with a TDS of 160. What did I just pay for? Worse quality water?

A TDS of 160 is really not that bad, but the main issue is that I just paid a lot of money for a “placebo” product.

I returned the filter and kept my old one for now.

title: Lasts 6 months for family of 6ppl
text:
Usually when I see a description that something “lasts 6 months” I think “yeah right, not for my family” because we are 6 people. This filter actually does last 6 months! My indicator light just turned from green to yellow and I’m a week shy of 6 months from my last date of purchase. That makes this filter extremely cost effective. I was using a water filtration pitcher that required changing roughly every two weeks with a filter that cost about $10!!

In terms of flavor, we have city water that when unfiltered does taste like chlorine. This removed the chlorine flavor. My mom is super picky about any chlorine taste in her water. I don’t always notice if a filter isn’t working as well, but she would definitely comment on my water flavor if I didn’t change the filter quick enough when I was using a filtering pitcher. Even after 5 months of use with this filter, my mom said that my water tasted good!

title: These lasted less than a month; normally we get 6 months out of them. Did we get used filters?
text:
We’ve been using this brand of filter in our fridge for 6 years. They always last about 6 months. I purchased these 2 filters in March and installed the first one a month ago. It lasted 3 weeks and then the flow died to a trickle. I swapped for the 2nd filter and that one lasted a single day. Removed the filter and ran the water dispenser, and verified the flow was strong. So I went and spent another $50 for a filter at Home Depot, and when installed the flow was back to normal.

I can’t shake the feeling I paid for 2 used filters on Amazon, and I’ll likely never buy from these vendors again.

title: Don't ask for more...
text:
We bought this at Amazon as a replacement for filter W10295370A. It fits, doesn't leak, and is easy to install. It does it's job as long as it's not asked to do more. Our city conducted it's annual 2 week long super chlorination of the municipal water system. Even though the filter was less than 3 months in use, this filter wasn't up to it. The chlorine taste bled through to both ice and water. We had to buy ice and bottled water at the supermarket. When the super chlorination effort ended, the filter resumed it's normal filtering function. No more chlorine taste. What's annoying is that the original equipment filters could handle the super chlorination. Deduct one star.

Another annoyance is that after a new filter is installed it requires 4 GALLONS ! of water to be flushed through the system before use. That seems excessive to me, and asking a great deal of the customer. Makes me wonder if the manufacturer might need to be encouraged to make a cleaner product. And there goes the second star.

And there's one more thing. It pops out. No reason, just pops out. I have to keep a carton of something shoved up against the door to keep it closed. Maybe it's only worth 2 stars.

title: No improvement over non filtered water with TDS meter
text:
I have a Whirlpool fridge and I received a filter replacement warning about 2 weeks ago. So, while at Home Depot I decided to pick up a new filter. After paying about $50 I installed the new filter and flushed it with 3 gallons of water. I then decided to compare my tap water to the filtered water in my fridge. To do so I filled a measuring cup up to the 300ml line then tested the water using a TDS meter. I took 6 different samples, 3 for the tap water and 3 for the filtered water. Here are my results in PPM.

Filtered and tap water results. The first reading in each column is the filtered water reading.

1. 50. 60

2. 49. 58

3. 50 59

I was quite disappointed to see no improvement with my new filter. I anticipated that after spending $50 that a new filter would improve water quality in respect to a PPM reading.

You may notice that my water quality is quite good in regards to the low PPM readings.

Above I provide photos of the best readings which were obtained on my second test run. It appears that the filter is actually leaving some sort of filtering sediment in the water. Maybe with time the filtered water may improve. I will update this review in the near future with additional readings to see if the filtered water improves over time with use.

title: Was this filter counterfeit?
text:
I bought this filter from Amazon rather that from my regular retailer for the first time. I now believe I obtained a counterfeit product. The water tasted wrong, almost as if it had permanent freezer burn. My wife told me to return it. I couldn't imagine that the brand new filter I just purchased was the problem. I thought something must be wrong with my refrigerator. After a few weeks and after realizing that we never had a problem until we installed the new water filter, I purchased a brand new one from my regular retailer. Our water tasted perfect again.

Now, I'm kind of livid. It was the filter! I was completely unaware of all the fake, counterfeit and junk products being sold on Amazon. After all, I buy so much stuff from Amazon that I never suspected that some of their third-party retailers are selling crap. Anyways, I'm unhappy with this purchase and will never make it again.

title: Lasted Only For Three Months
text: Received one on May 9, installed it right away and filtered water immediately tasted great. However, it lasted only for three months; I started noticing the bad smell/taste of unfiltered water in August. Now in September, the water tastes awful. I used this product for my Whirlpool refrigerator and it fit just fine. So my complaint is that this product works but only for three months. From the price point, I am clearly not satisfied. This is supposed to last twice longer.

title: Good product
text: I have only installed this and had it one day but what can I say, it's a water filter. It does exactly what it is supposed to do. I'm pretty sure all the people complaining about the taste and  The water being foggy don't follow directions. You have to flush a lot of water through first (4 gallons). The water only looks foggy because a filter is hundreds of thousand porous holes squeezing water through and that's how it's filtered.  So for the first few days you are getting all those little bubbles from the porous holes. It goes away after a couple of days. Tastes good

title: practice installing
text:
This is the filter my refrigerator takes. Therefore my choice is limited to this product.
It filters fairly well and reduces the taste of tap water.
I struggled to install it. First I put it in upside down. Then I had difficulty getting it to fully insert the last inch or so. And the refrigerator door, which opens left to right and hits a wall in my kitchen, made it difficult to reach the back of the frig and apply sufficient pressure to fully insert the filter.

title: Paying For Annoyance
text: This is the second filter we've run through a brand new refrigerator. It came with the old version which, even though it filtered less contaminants, had much higher flow rate and tasted far superior. Interestingly enough, this new version of the filter states it's flow rate is higher. Additionally, this new version has a poor fit. It's even popped out before (which I know I'll get some eye rolls for), but this ain't my first rodeo...or second, for that matter. All combined, it's nearly impossible to clear the line of air. I chalk this all up to a combined lack of quality control on behalf of Whirlpool. The old version of this filter is abundant online, which we're switching back to. For now, we'll have to drink the pharma water with an additional 17 contaminants so we don't have to deal with the Flubber machine.

title: Great replacement filter for Whirlpool fridge
text: I was skeptical about buying the water filter after all the negative reviews, but it surprised me. My fridge was new and this is the first time I had to change the filter. Whatever filter was already IN the fridge had a terrible plastic taste so I was concerned that it would stay around with the new filter. To my big surprise it was much better. I only drink spring water and have drank from the filter and liked it- it had no after taste or plastic taste anymore. I did have some air bubbles following the filter change but it does go away after a little while. I made sure to run the water before the first use (as directed) although I didn't measure the water so was it exactly however many gallons??? No idea! I am very happy with my purchase and will only order this filter for my Whirpool fridge.

title: These are triggered by TIME (i.e. 6 months, then they say they need to be replaced)...  Total scam
text:
This is one of the biggest rip offs I've seen in a long time.

This thing appears to be TIME based, meaning, it's good for 6 months, then, it sets off the bright red and somewhat alarming 'REPLACE FILTER" icon.

I've used this filter, maybe, 10 times.

That's $5 for every glass of water I've put through it.

Talk about a scam.

title: Worse than tap water from the sink

the tap water has no chorine smell . Unfortunately , I threw away the packaging ,

purchasers return the old ones , and they're resold . I'm going to Lowes or Home Depot .

Update: Amazon refunded the amount in full .

title: NOT RECYCLABLE! This creates a lot of waste
text:
I really enjoy using this product. It's easy to use and produce clean tasting water. However, Whirlpool does not recycle this project. In fact, they asked you to pay $9+ to buy an envelope kit to ship this to their partner facility. AND, the recycling kit is currently out of stock. After a year of using this you'll end up with multiple plastic cartridges that clutter landfill.

Unfortunately I won't be repurchasing it until Whirlpool put some effort into recycling their products.

title: Perfect replacement part
text: This was the perfect replacement part for my KitchenAid refrigerator. All I had to do was lift the flap, slide out the filter that was in place, take the cap off the replacement, pop it in the place where the last filter was seated (it can only go in one way so no worries about making sure it is in the correct way), and then snap down the flap. By closing the flap, it pushed the filter into place and secured it. Be sure to check the number on the side of your old filter when ordering. This is number ONE; the different numbered filters come in different sizes. I gave it 4 stars because of the cost. $50 is stupid for a water filter.

title: Reduced water flow after two months
text: The EveryDrop #1 water filter was easy to install in a Kitchen Aid Side-by-Side refrigerator. The water filter worked fine for two months and then started greatly reducing the water flow. The reduction caused the water pump to work harder and longer than necessary. It also caused the water measurement feature to become very inaccurate. I took the water filter out and checked that the water pressure was ok and also cleaned the nozzle. All to no avail. Previous EveryDrop filters have worked fine and lasted the expected six months.  I replaced the filter with a new EveryDrop filter and the water flow is fine. I expect more from a manufacturer recommended replacement part. This water filter is too expensive to last only two months, just long enough so it can't be returned. .

title: This product was useful but I prefer a lower price for this product
text: This product was hard for me to find and choose. Finding Whirlpool/Amanda water filters for my fridge unit took a lot of time and effort until I finally came to this product. Although I feel that the price for this product is too high, it was one of the only options we'd got to find a filter that would replace our outdated water filter in our fridge. I was hoping to find a water filter branded by either Whirlpool/Amanda or at least the same brand as the filter they've already installed in my fridge. This product was bought because our old filter reached its 6-month limit and after a few months of use, the water change taste. We had no choice but to but a new one and luckily we found this filter which was compatible. After installing, you have to throw out some of the water and ice from the fridge as instructed in the manual. To install, there is this square compartment on the bottom of the fridge (outside). Pull it and the filter pops right out. Replace and push tight to close the compartment. This product was useful but I prefer a lower price for this product.

title: MASSIVE Quality Control Issues 4/4 FAILED
text:
There are huge quality control issues with this filter compared to the older purple 'Pur' ones. Of four new filters we tried three of them don't pass water at all. The fourth filter makes the water line ping sounding like a machine gun. There is a video on youtube where someone posted similar issue and the response in the comments was to try and insert a piece of paper towel between the filter and the closing door cover as you force the filter in. I tried this and water did flow for a few seconds but then stopped. DO NOT BUY THIS FILTER, BIG ISSUES.

Update 2019-JUN-22: I tried again to monkey with these filters, same issue. I uploaded an image which I think shows the issue. The filter on the right from October 2018 works fine. The filter on the left is one of the filters which does not work. If you look at the groves cut into the filter projections, just above the black o-rings, you will see that the groves on the filter that works (on the right) are slightly smaller than the groves on the filter on the left (which does not work). If this is the issue, and it looks like it is, then the filter is not allowed to connect securely enough to the connections to allow water to flow through it properly. I have gone through SIX new filters trying to make them work. The EveryDrop white ones and the older design purple Pur ones. None of the ones I have purchased during 2019 work correctly.

title: Adds sulfur smell and taste to otherwise normal water.
text: This filter was delivered and installed on March 20th of this year. Instead of filtering the water of impurities it added them. Normally smell-less and tasteless water immediately had a strong sulfur smell and taste to it. This led to the sink being the main source of water for drinking. The smell and taste persisted, with the occasional test, to this date when it finally became unbearable. With the filter removed and the old water flushed from the system the water was smell-less and tasteless again. Not only was the filter in effective but actually made the water worse. Recommend this filter be avoided at all cost.

I went on Amazon to see if I could get a free replacement but I'd have to return the old one. That is not easy to do. It's wet, it's been used and is still being used until we can replace it.

title: Have the water despensed out of this filter tested and see for yourself
text:
When you first install the filter the instructions have you flush four gallons through. I followed the instructions and even emptied the ice maker so it could flush the filter a bit more by making ice.

The next few weeks we would fill a glass of water and notice after a few hours the water smelt like plastic with an odd taste. You can't notice it unless the water warms up. This does go away after a month of use but i'm wondering what i'm drinking.

I've decided I'm going to send the water to be analyzed and will respond to this review once it comes back. I dont want my newborn or wife drinking out of the fridge until then. I miss the original PUR clear filters. When they switched to the solid plastic everything went down hill.

Thankfully the municipal water here is actually pretty good so instead of wasting money on the filter, I'm just leaving it out.

I thought about it again, why am I just settling... so I went onto amazon and read some of the reviews and there was someone else with a similar issue.  They purchased a new filter from the local home depot and it worked just fine. Do I really wanna spend another $45.00 on another one? I purchased this in october 2020 so my return window is up. It doesn’t last nearly as long as it should.  And the cost is pretty high in my opinion for how often it needs to be changed.  The Whirlpool refrigerator came with our new home, so it’s what we are “stuck” with until it’s justified to purchase a new one.  When we do, we will go to an LG.  The water and filtration system on those are SO much easier to change and a much greater value.

Also, if it does say somewhere on the instructions that you need to flush it with 4 gallons after installing it please make that easier to find, because I couldn't see it anywhere. Tried finding a different brand that would fit my fridge but everything either has poor reviews or won't get here for a week, so the manufacturer kind of has me feeling like I have no choice. Fortunately my local Lowes has plenty in stock, so I'm returning this paperweight and picking one up there. What a waste of time and more importantly, water!!! Whirlpool: Make a better product or change this one's name to "Every drop...after flushing a minimum 4 gallons through it, then it'll last for a month if you're lucky" and stop screwing average consumers like me with your overpriced junk!!!

title: Works for a cup or two, then grinds to hault
text:
Having same issue as so many other reviewers. Filter slides in fine, but door closes with resistance. That was first red flag that something changed. After clearing a couple gallons as instructed, we only get a few more cups of filtered water before the (now familiar) grinding noise happens and all flow slows to a hault. Overnight, it will filter 1/4 cup and stop again, grinding with each attemp for flow.
I’ve replaced the filter 4 times in one month. Have not had luck with ANY of the replacements. Thank God for Amazon’s return policy.
We are now looking for non-Whirlpool appliances (we have to replace all of them so they match) that will allow us to have clean water. These appliances are only 2 years old. Anyone know of a class-action lawsuit pending??

title: Defective/wrong size filter cost me $150 dollars + much grief
text:
I ordered these many times over the years, and there had never been an issue. I made the mistake of going on Amazon's auto-purchase system, which led me to keep the filter on the shelf for some time before use, making a refund request impossible. I actually thought the refrigerator had a major malfunction--shortly after installing the filter, not only did the water stop flowing, but the refrigerator made loud banging and whirring noises. I called an appliance repair person. He identified that the filter had frozen, warmed it up and reinstalled it, water was flowing again. Charged me about $100. Within two hours, the problem was back. At least I now knew that the water filter was the problem. Searching the internet, I found this was a known problem with some of the recently sold filters of this type--their casings are apparently the wrong size (counterfeit?). Following a "tip," I folded some paper towels and taped them to the filter before reinstalling, leading to a tighter seal. That worked, but just for a day or two. I went though months of having this problem the water would stop/noise start, I'd remove the filter and reinstall it, it worked again for a short while. I finally gave up, threw out the offending filter and installed another that was on my shelf from the (now cancelled) Amazon subscription. That one worked, no problem. But this was a big pain, I'll buy direct from the manufacturer in the future.

Added info, 5/22: I made the mistake of ordering another of these from Amazon. Same problem--the fit is slightly off, so the soon the fridge starts up with a grinding/hammering noise, etc. This time, I was able to return it and reordered direct from the manufacture. So far no problems with the manufacturer-direct filters. This is a small sample size (two defective units), but I will not again order these from Amazon, and I hope Amazon will take a close look into their source for these filters, which may be different from the bona fide units.

title: Honest Review
text:
First thing I want to point out is the other reviews on this item that talk about TDS. First and foremost you are not buying this filter to remove TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) you need a RO/RODI (Reverse osmosis) filter unit in order to remove TDS. At the most this filter is a sediment filter (removes undissolved solids) to a point and then uses a carbon block to remove other chemicals from the water (ex: Chlorine, smells, taste, etc.) Overall just makes the water a bit healthier and cleaner with a “better” taste apposed to tap. Also helps prevent larger particles from building up in the fridge without removing 100% of everything in the water. Again research RODI units if you want 100% “clean, 0 TDS” water.

Other then that it does have a good taste to the water.
My biggest complaint is the cost. On average they last 6 months at $50 not on sale that’s approx $8.35 a month excluding tax. For a water filter. Compared to other filter styles that don’t fit this filter. I personally plan on letting the fridge bypass the filter and doing my own DIY filter in-line before it gets to the fridge. Other than the initial start up costs (less than $150) it will be approx $25 every 6 months to a year depending on use for my planned DIY filter that will accomplish the same thing as this.

title: Expensive but worth it
text: We've purchased a few off-brand filters in the past and they seem to have two problems: 1. taste is weird or 2. water pressure because the filter clogs or goes bad faster than these. So, from here on out, we've vowed to purchase only the OEM filters for our Whirlpool refrigerator. Taste is great (and yes, I'm one of those odd people who can easily tell the difference between brands of bottled water, various pitcher filters, and tap) with no odd odors or aftertastes. And we've had no issues with the water pressure as time goes on. As we near the end of the 6 months these are suggested for, I will have to adjust the auto-fill because it starts to slow a bit. Otherwise, no issues with these filters and even though yes, they are expensive - it's worth it to us.

title: Newer fliters are clogging
text:
I enjoy the simplicity of the design; lift the door, pull out the old filter, put in the new one, flush, and you're done.

But the last two filters I've gotten have started to clog long before their service life is due. It is just three people in my house. We don't have parties where we're chewing through water and ice. The last two filters I've got have clogged well before the six month reminder on my refrigerator comes due. I should have two months left on this filter, I don't.

I thought my water pump on my refrigerator went out, so I ordered I new one. Tried looking up bypass valves for my refrigerator and found out it has an automatic bypass when the filter is out. Took out the filter and my water works now. Hence, the filter is clogged. The last two filters clogged before the end of life.

I'm tired of paying close to fifty dollars for a product that can't complete it's own service life.

So, I located this product, which is a replacement to the one Whirlpool used to make for my fridge. It costs more than the non-OEM product I was using, but it worked as soon as I installed it, and it continues to work. I wish there was a more reasonably priced product, but I've learned my lesson about buying cheap products - sometimes they cost more in the long run when they don't work! I will continue to order these filters from now on.

title: HMMMM...
text:
Something is fishy here. The indicator light on my fridge had turned yellow (meaning I needed to order a replacement filter) so I did just that. My new EveryDrop filter comes in the mail quick as can be, but I haven't changed it yet since the light hasn't turned red yet. Everything is hunky-dory.

BUT THEN. We had a power outage for several hours. And when the power came back on, the indicator light was green again. This seems incredibly scummy to me. This indicates that the fridge doesn't have a "real" way to determine whether a filter is in good shape- it possibly only goes by how long it has been in the fridge or how much water it has already filtered (and I'm not even sure it would be possible for the filter or fridge to keep track of how much water it has filtered.) If my filter was really "bad" my indicator light should still be yellow.

So take that as you will. The actual water is delicious, no complaints there. The only reason I deducted those stars is because of what seems like an obvious money grubbing ploy. Make people believe that the filter is going bad so they buy an overpriced filter. My fridge is only 4 months old anyway, it hasn't been used THAT long. I did not think I'd have to be paying 44 bucks every 4 months for simple upkeep of my fridge.

I ordered another filter feeling i got a defective filter, the new filter arrived and i replaced the defective filter with the new one. A few days later, the problem started again. I had a technician come check the the refrigerator who informed me the refrigerator was fine, and that it was another defective filter. I just received today 1-6-22 my 3rd filter, as of now the system is working. It appears quality control with this company is failing!!! title: Massive quality control/Supplier issues! Avoid!
text:
These things have massive Quality Control issues - takes multiple attempts to install and get water to pass through and after just 2.5 months this thing is dispensing at a turtles-pace and my fridge was already indicating it needed replacement

Unfortunately there aren’t many alternatives aside from Going to a local hardware store etc. it’s possible that just this supplier is pushing shady products. Will be shopping local for these from now on, the water tastes fine though.

title: Use the factory part ONLY!
text:
We had friends who purchased the Amazon part rather than the factory part and it exploded inside their fridge. Water everywhere. So at our house we use ONLY the factory part in this case.
We use knock-off printer cartridges and many other “copy” parts, but this one is critical.
Be warned!

title: Las entregas Prime están fallando con frecuencia
text: Nada que criticar al producto, lo he comprado ya varias veces. Mi insatisfacción es con respecto al servicio Prime que pago desde unos años con la idea de recibir entregas rápidas sin recargos, pero desde hace un tiempo se incumplen las fechas ofrecidas y en más de una caso he vivido la experiencia de no haber recibido nunca lo que compré y me ha tocado pedir reembolso. Considero que hay una sustancial desmejora en el servicio de entregas de Amazon, ese punto ha sido considerado por mí como una fortaleza desde hace muchos años en los que he sido cliente. Lo peor es que no hay compensación en los casos en que falla el servicio prometido, impropio de una firma de esa magnitud y peso. Les recomiendo tomar acción al respecto, evitará que se busquen alternativas dejando de un lado la  confianza que se han ganado.

title: Chlorine Flavor
text:
I purchased this to replace the original filter that came with the refrigerator when it was installed earlier this year. After installation, the water from the dispenser immediately began tasting like chlorine. The chlorine flavor worsened over the first week, so I removed the filter and flushed the dispenser with five gallons of water. The chlorine flavor disappeared, so I left the filter out for a few weeks.

Last week I decided to try again. After reinstalling the filter, I flushed it with five gallons of water. Unfortunately, the chlorine flavor immediately returns and keeps intensifying.

title: Pretty useless
text:
These fridge water filters don't do much. Super expensive for what it is, and doesn't really filter much. I've been ordering these filters religiously every time I get notification and recently purchased a Digital water tester. I tested regular tap water from the faucet and it read 94 ppm, then tested the water from the fridge with a filter that was about 3 weeks old and it read 89 ppm!!!
Better to save your money and invest in a Reverse osmosis system which will bring it down to single digits, under 10 ppm. I'm getting an under sink Reverse osmosis system and run a line directly to the fridge and just remove these useless fridge filters. I mean how much can you expect these things to filter? It's tiny and only 1 stage. A Reverse osmosis system has at least 3 stages (the one I got has 5 stages) and each filter is 3 times the size of these.

title: Working behind the scene to keep the water clean
text: Our 18 month old Kitchenaid Refrigerator is the first we've had to require a water filter. Our previous Kitchenaid 'frig lasted 25 years with no filter. As projections go, that will be 50+ filters if this one lasts as long. With honesty, I can't tell any difference in the water or ice from the last unit or from the 10x amount of water we get straight from the tap.  But, this Everydrop filter does its job, quietly, continually, only yelling for a replacement about every 6 months. Guess that's progress.

title: Overpriced, underperforming, Whirlpool scam
text: So I’ve purchased this filter for over $50. Which is a ripoff. The only reason it’s so expensive is because Whirlpool makes their special filters hard to reproduce, so it’s either whirlpool or some sketchy Chinese filter. I’ve used both. Both are pretty much exactly the same. They last 6 months. Water flavor doesn’t change. Water quality doesn’t change. I’d like to just gut one of these filters and use it as a bypass instead of paying $60 every 6 months to slow down my water flow. Usually I go 8-10 months between changing filters because there’s really no difference. Next fridge I buy I will make sure it has no filter or standard filters that are reasonably priced and offered by multiple suppliers. I can’t see this filter costing more than $2.50 to manufacture. Selling for nearly $60 now is just price gouging and Whirlpool finding a new way to make more money rather than providing a solid product.

title: Quality drop
text: We've used these water filters since 2017. They always lasted 6 months as described, no real issues.  Starting in 2021, we noticed water coming out in a trickle.  It takes forever to fill a glass.  We changed the filter, problem solved, for about 2 months.  Then like clockwork, the water pressure decreases significantly, and will decrease more and more until the filter is changed.  They are only lasting about 3 months now, and that last month is miserable with the water trickling.

title: Worthless
text:
Quite frankly, I do not like to write truly negative reviews. I bought one of the filters to replace the one on my new Whirlpool 28 cu ft fridge/freezer. The PPD was exactly the same as from my unfiltered water faucet, i.e. it didn't do a darned thing. I thought that maybe this was just a bad one, and bought another from Home Depot. Exactly the same result in that there was zero effective filtration.
I ended up installing a 3/8" six stage water filtration unit under the sink with a 3/8" - 1/4" adaptor (from Amazon) and piped it to the fridge. Hey presto! - I now have awesome filtered water and ice cubes. Note: the 3/8" filter size is necessary to provide sufficient pressure to the fridge.
To me, these small in-fridge filters are totally useless.

title: filters water, but...
text:
I have used these filters for many years. Mostly, when my fridge starts making chattering noises, it is an indicator that i need to change the filter - so I do. After that, chatter gone.
Except this time - when I installed this filter, the chatter came back in less than a week. i had to remove the filter, replace it, and try again before the chatter went away (mostly). it almost sounds like some air=bubble trapped in the system is causing a rushing noise and then the chatter.
I will keep an eye on it, and if it happens again, i will swap to a new filter - though that it is an expensive fix after just a month of service for a filter of this price.

title: Four Different Filters, None Work
text:
UPDATE: I am revising my review because I was incorrect with my conclusions. I finally got a technician to look at my problem and he said that it something he has seen before and it is air in the water line. His only advice was to keep working at it until the air is gone. I gave up after a while and just removed the fiter entirely. My model fridge does not require a plug. I'm somewhat annoyed with Whirlpool support; I can't be the only person to have had this problem.

I've tried four different filters with no success. With three of the filters, there was a loud hammering sound that persisted and sounded like it could damage the fridge. With this last purchase, there is a brief hammering noice then no water comes out of the dispenser, just a drop or two no matter how long I try. When I put the old filter back in, the water flows with no problem. Unfortunately, I let the return window close so I am stuck with it.

I should add that I chatted with Whirlpool support. Apparently they have no history of this sort of problem. Their suggestion was to try another filter --which I did-- and if that didn't work --it didn't-- place a service call. They also recommended that I check if my model fridge is still eligible for their service plan. If I place a one-time service call for this problem then I become ineligible for their service plan. Either way, it sounds expensive.

I am at a loss as to how to get a replacement filter. Has anyone had luck with off-brand, non-Whirlpool filters.

title: "Authenticity" does not matter with these filters.
text:
Some of these filters don't allow the water to flow through them. This was replaced in December, and it is already not working.
The only way to allow water to flow through the front is to remove the faulty filter. When replacing the same filter, the refrigerator makes a loud, repetitive clicking noise as it tries to pull the water through, to no avail. Out of 4, this is the second filter received that has done this. I thought it was the refrigerator at first, but after removing the filter, the water flowed through just fine. It must be the manufacturer, who tells us to only purchase the filters with the proof of authenticity on them. I have, so this is not the truth. The cost of these filters is way too much for the uselessness.

title: Do not buy these from Amazon
text: This brand of filter is fine. Just don't buy these from Amazon. I don't know if the product is counterfeit or gets damaged in shipping or what, but it takes less than a week for the water flow to turn into a pathetic trickle. Go buy these from your local hardware store instead, even if it costs a few bucks more. Twice now I've ordered these from Amazon and they lasted less than a month before I got frustrated with the flow rate and replaced them early. The ones I buy locally last what the rating says on the box (~6 months).

title: Received a Used Cartridge
text: The filter light came on my refrigerator about an hour ago. I went to install a replacement filter I had purchased last year and my fridge automatically kicked the cartridge right back out. I shook the new replacement cartridge and heard that it was nearly full of water which told me it was a used cartridge. Thankfully, I was able to run around the corner to Lowe's to purchase two replacements cartridges. I have been using these cartridges for about three years now and have never had a problem. My concern is that it was sold and packaged as new but was clearly used. It is also way past the date when I can return it to receive a replacement. Hopefully, it won't happen again because I really liked the convenience of being able to order two replacements per year and having them delivered to my doorstep.

title: Defective Filter; No Return or Refund
text: Do not buy these Whirlpool filters from Amazon, because they may be defective.  I had the same experience as others, who have written reviews.  I bought two filters to have in hand when it came time to replace one.  Six weeks later the display indicated it was time, so I replaced the old filter with the one I received from Amazon.  The new filter made a grinding motor sound and barely dripped water, just as others said happened to them.  I re-installed the filter several times with the same results. Then I tried the second filter I purchased, and it would not wok either.  I've had the refrigerator for 15 years and have never had any problem with factory filter replacements.  I then went to Lowe's and bought the same factory filter.  It only took a few minutes to install it, and the system worked perfectly. I can't imagine why the Amazon filters were defective, but they are.  To make matters even worse, because I didn't discover the problem until 6 weeks after I purchased them, I could not get a refund or replacement.  The 30-day return policy of Amazon for this class of product had expired, so I LOST OVER $90.  This company has no provision for fairly selling this type of product, where they can routinely fail or be defective.  Don't buy factory filters from Amazon.  Go to your local businesses, where they will always honor your purchases when you have a legitimate problem.  There is no reason why I should have been ripped off by Amazon, with no recourse to talk to a customer representative or any other normal process to get my money back due to their failures.

I don't feel comfortable drinking water through this filter. I have read other user reviews and will follow their advice - Purchase the filter from my local Home Depot. I expect this type of result from generic filters but not an OEM replacement.

title: If you are wondering why your water tastes bad it may not be the filter.
text:
I purchase a new Whirlpool French Door Fridge earlier this month. After running 4 gallons through, and dumping the first few batches of ice the water was funky. The water had a bad chemical plastic taste that did not diminish with additional flushing. I read several reviews on the previous generation filter (same as my new fridge) with the same complaint. I was ready to send the fridge back. I did a little information gathering on appliance repair sites and discovered source of the problem and occam's razor came to mind. It was the new steel braided ice maker supply line (mine was a Watts brand made in China) I bought it new for the fridge. Read reviews of various ice maker supply lines and you will see there is a serious problem with many manufacturers.

Anyway I ordered a Whirlpool 8212547RP 5-Feet Pex Ice Maker Hook-up Kit from Amazon for about 8 bucks with tax (same material as the rest of the fridge's plumbing) and the water tastes fine now. I replaced my original filter just because I considered the original to be contaminated. The new filter tastes fine, although I am docking stars for the high price, although I imagine that it will come down in price as its a new product with limited supply at the moment.

If you are suffering from that chemical taste: unless you have a copper, pex or a quality confirmed ice make supply line then you owe it to yourself to at least test it. Pull your fridge out, turn the supply valve off, disconnect the supply line from the fridge. Fill a glass with water directly from the supply line and taste it. If it tastes worse than tap then you know its the ice maker supply line.

I honestly wonder about the economics of how many refrigerators and filters have been returned because the ice maker supply line is of poor quality.

title: Water flow slows to a trickle after 3-4 weeks
text:
[[VIDEOID:709f0cbd52541726e9c46a943998e32]] I'm very disappointed in these filters. Not only are they quite expensive compared to other brands, but we bought a pack of 2 of this same model (from the Whirlpool website) and we had to replace the first one after ~4 weeks because the water started coming out so incredibly slowly. The 2nd filter in the pack dispensed water at a usable rate at first, and then it reduced to a trickle after 3-4 weeks as well. It's so slow now, it takes ~7-8 minutes to fill 1 liter (e.g. a SodaStream 1L bottle).

In the video -- I'm not sure why it comes out at a weird angle, but as far as we can tell there is no blockage --- in fact when we replaced the filter with a new one, it stopped coming out at a weird angle for ~3 weeks until the problem started up again. This is definitely not a problem with our water; we recently replaced our fridge, and the previous fridge did not have this problem. We have used Brita filters that did not have this problem.

We're going to have to get an attachment on our sink because it's too expensive to buy 1 filter every 3 weeks! I'm going to post this same review on the Whirlpool website.
